transcripts.text: The ideas, visions, dreams, and plans that we have are obviously not the same as the Word of God.  Let's watch part of an in-church training video from Craig Groeschel, the mega-pastor of the mega-church Life.Church, one of the biggest churches on earth.

Life.Church So many people wander through life.  They stumble, trying to make some sort of a difference, but never seem to end up somewhere significant.  In fact, in the Kazon experience, we'll say again and again that everyone ends up somewhere, but few people end up somewhere on purpose.  Everyone ends up somewhere, but few people have a plan, have a vision, but few people have a plan, have a vision, and end up in a very specific place because God led them to that place.

This is the setup for the rest of his talk.  You need a plan or vision to accomplish your goals.  God has specific stuff for you to do, but you need to figure it out based on the desires or talents inside of you.  You need to have a kazone experience.

The good news is that before you even existed, God knew you, He shaped you, and He created you, put you at this moment in history because your gifts, your talents, your passions are best designed for you to glorify God at this moment in history.  And I believe as you seek God prayerfully that you're not just going to end up somewhere, but you're going to end up somewhere on purpose.  So, the Kazon experience will help you do two things.  The first thing is you're going to prayerfully discover God's purpose for you.  for your life, and number two, you're going to develop a realistic plan to start working toward living out that purpose.  Because everyone ends up somewhere, but few people end up somewhere on purpose.  And I believe with all my heart that living with a purpose is the difference between just existing and thriving in the way that you live.  Wow, I never thought of it that way.  That's really something.  So, you may say, what is kazon?  Well, kazon comes from Proverbs 29, 18.  And you attribute all this to the calzone?  Yeah.  And the Bible says, where there is no vision, the people perish.

This half of a Bible verse must be translated in the King James Version, otherwise this whole motivational speech thingy that he's doing falls apart.  Here's the whole verse in a couple of different translations.  Where there is no prophecy, the people cast off restraint, but happy are those who keep the law.  Where there is no prophetic vision, the people cast off restraint, but blessed is he who keeps the law.  Where there is no vision, the people are unrestrained, but happy is he who keeps the law.  Where people do not accept divine guidance, they run wild, but whoever obeys the law is joyful.  This Bible verse is really about listening to God's word and obeying God's word.  It has nothing to do with visualizing your goals or dreaming about your purpose in life.

where there is no vision.  The word in the Hebrew that's translated as vision is the word chazon.  To say it the right way, you almost have to act like you're clearing your throat like that, but don't do that if someone's sitting too close to you.  But it's chazon, C-H-A-Z-O-W-N.  And this word means a dream, a revelation, or vision.

Notice which word is not underlined.  He doesn't want you to think about revelation very much because that refers to God's word.  He's twisting this verse to make it fit his purpose.  It's not about what God says, it's about what you feel inside yourself.  None of these definitions mean plan, but this whole Kazone experience is about making specific plans based on your visions.
